'''Frst-order hold''' ('''FOH''') is a mathematical model of the practical reconstruction of sampled signals that could be done by a conventional [[digital-to-analog converter]] (DAC) and an [[analog circuit]] called an [[integrator]]. For FOH, the signal is reconstructed as a [[Piecewise linear function|piecewise linear]] approximation to the original signal that was sampled. A mathematical model such as FOH (or, more commonly, the [[zero-order hold]]) is necessary because, in the [[Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem|sampling and reconstruction theorem]], a sequence of [[Dirac delta function|Dirac impulses]], ''x''<sub>s</sub>(''t''), representing the discrete samples, ''x''(''nT''), is [[low-pass filter]]ed to recover the original signal that was sampled, ''x''(''t''). However, outputting a sequence of Dirac impulses is impractical. Devices can be implemented, using a conventional DAC and some linear analog circuitry, to reconstruct the piecewise linear output for either predictive or delayed FOH.
Even though this is ''not'' what is physically done, an identical output can be generated by applying the hypothetical sequence of Dirac impulses, ''x''<sub>s</sub>(''t''), to a [[Linear time-invariant theory|linear time-invariant system]], otherwise known as a [[electronic filter|linear filter]] with such characteristics (which, for an LTI system, are fully described by the [[impulse response]]) so that each input impulse results in the correct piecewise linear function in the output.
==Basic first-order hold== [[Image:Sampled.signal.svg|thumb|Ideally sampled signal ''x''<sub>s</sub>(''t'').]]
First-order hold is the hypothetical [[filter (signal processing)|filter]] or [[LTI system]] that converts the ideally sampled signal
:{| |- |<math>x_s(t)\,</math> |<math>= x(t) \ T \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t - nT) \ </math> |- | |<math>= T \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} x(nT) \delta(t - nT) \ </math> |}
[[Image:Firstorderhold.signal.svg|thumb|Piecewise linear signal ''x''<sub>FOH</sub>(''t'').]]
to the piecewise linear signal
:<math>x_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t)\,= \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} x(nT) \mathrm{tri} \left(\frac{t - nT}{T} \right) \ </math>
[[Image:Firstorderhold.impulseresponse.svg|thumb|Impulse response (non-causal) of first-order hold ''h''<sub>FOH</sub>(''t'').]]
resulting in an effective [[impulse response]] of
: <math>h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t)\,= \frac{1}{T} \mathrm{tri} \left(\frac{t}{T} \right) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{T} \left( 1 - \frac{|t|}{T} \right) & \mbox{if } |t| < T \\ 0 & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases} \ </math>
: where <math>\mathrm{tri}(x) \ </math> is the [[triangular function]].
The effective frequency response is the [[continuous Fourier transform]] of the impulse response.
:{| |- |<math>H_{\mathrm{FOH}}(f)\,</math> |<math>= \mathcal{F} \{ h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t) \} \ </math> |- | |<math>= \left( \frac{e^{i \pi fT} - e^{-i \pi fT}}{i 2 \pi fT} \right)^2 \ </math> |- | |<math>= \mathrm{sinc}^2(fT) \ </math> |}
: where <math>\mathrm{sinc}(x) = \frac{\sin(\pi x)}{\pi x} \ </math> is the normalized [[sinc function]].
The [[Laplace transform]] [[transfer function]] of FOH is found by substituting ''s'' = ''i'' 2 π ''f'':
:{| |- |<math>H_{\mathrm{FOH}}(s)\,</math> |<math>= \mathcal{L} \{ h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t) \} \ </math> |- | |<math>= \left( \frac{e^{sT/2} - e^{-sT/2}}{sT} \right)^2 \ </math> |}
This is an [[acausal system]] in that the linear interpolation function moves toward the value of the next sample before such sample is applied to the hypothetical FOH filter.
==Delayed first-order hold== [[Image:Delayedfirstorderhold.signal.svg|thumb|Delayed piecewise linear signal ''x''<sub>FOH</sub>(''t'').]]
'''Delayed first-order hold''', sometimes called '''causal first-order hold''', is identical to FOH above except that its output is delayed by one [[sampling frequency|sample period]] resulting in a delayed piecewise linear output signal
:<math>x_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t)\,= \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} x(nT) \mathrm{tri} \left(\frac{t - T - nT}{T} \right) \ </math>
[[Image:Delayedfirstorderhold.impulseresponse.svg|thumb|Impulse response of causal first-order hold ''h''<sub>FOH</sub>(''t'').]]
resulting in an effective [[impulse response]] of
: <math>h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t)\,= \frac{1}{T} \mathrm{tri} \left(\frac{t-T}{T} \right) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{T} \left( 1 - \frac{|t-T|}{T} \right) & \mbox{if } |t-T| < T \\ 0 & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases} \ </math>
: where <math>\mathrm{tri}(x) \ </math> is the [[triangular function]].
The effective frequency response is the [[continuous Fourier transform]] of the impulse response.
:{| |- |<math>H_{\mathrm{FOH}}(f)\,</math> |<math>= \mathcal{F} \{ h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t) \} \ </math> |- | |<math>= \left( \frac{1 - e^{-i 2\pi fT}}{i 2 \pi fT} \right)^2 \ </math> |- | |<math>= e^{-i 2 \pi fT} \mathrm{sinc}^2(fT) \ </math> |}
: where <math>\mathrm{sinc}(x) \ </math> is the [[sinc function]].
The [[Laplace transform]] [[transfer function]] of the delayed FOH is found by substituting ''s'' = ''i'' 2 π ''f'':
:{| |- |<math>H_{\mathrm{FOH}}(s)\,</math> |<math>= \mathcal{L} \{ h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t) \} \ </math> |- | |<math>= \left( \frac{1 - e^{-sT}}{sT} \right)^2 \ </math> |}
The delayed output makes this a [[causal system]]. The impulse response of the delayed FOH does not respond before the input impulse.
This kind of delayed piecewise linear reconstruction is physically realizable by implementing a [[digital filter]] of gain ''H''(''z'') = 1 − ''z''<sup>−1</sup>, applying the output of that digital filter (which is simply ''x''[''n'']−''x''[''n''−1]) to an ideal conventional [[digital-to-analog converter]] (that has an inherent [[zero-order hold]] as its model) and integrating (in continuous-time, ''H''(''s'') = 1/(''sT'')) the DAC output.
==Predictive first-order hold== [[Image:Predictivefirstorderhold.signal.svg|thumb|Predictive FOH output signal ''x''<sub>FOH</sub>(''t'').]]
Lastly, the '''predictive first-order hold''' is quite different. This is a ''causal'' hypothetical LTI system or filter that converts the ideally sampled signal
:{| |- |<math>x_s(t)\,</math> |<math>= x(t) \ T \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t - nT) \ </math> |- | |<math>= T \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} x(nT) \delta(t - nT) \ </math> |}
into a piecewise linear output such that the current sample and immediately previous sample are used to linearly [[extrapolate]] up to the next sampling instance. The output of such a filter would be
:{| |- |<math>x_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t)\,</math> |<math>= \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \left( x(nT) + \left( x(nT) - x((n-1)T) \right) \frac{t-nT}{T} \right) \mathrm{rect} \left(\frac{t - nT}{T} - \frac{1}{2} \right) \ </math> |- | |<math>= \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} x(nT) \left( \mathrm{rect} \left(\frac{t - nT}{T} - \frac{1}{2} \right) - \mathrm{rect} \left(\frac{t - nT}{T} - \frac{3}{2} \right) + \mathrm{tri} \left(\frac{t - nT}{T} - 1 \right) \right) \ </math> |}
[[Image:Predictivefirstorderhold.impulseresponse.svg|thumb|Impulse response of predictive first-order hold ''h''<sub>FOH</sub>(''t'').]]
resulting in an effective [[impulse response]] of
:{| |- |<math>h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t)\,</math> |<math>= \frac{1}{T} \left( \mathrm{rect} \left(\frac{t}{T} - \frac{1}{2} \right) - \mathrm{rect} \left(\frac{t}{T} - \frac{3}{2} \right) + \mathrm{tri} \left(\frac{t}{T} -1 \right) \right) \ </math> |- | |<math>= \begin{cases} \frac{1}{T} \left( 1 + \frac{t}{T} \right) & \mbox{if } 0 \le t < T \\ \frac{1}{T} \left( 1 - \frac{t}{T} \right) & \mbox{if } T \le t < 2T \\ 0 & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases} \ </math> |}
: where <math>\mathrm{rect}(x) \ </math> is the [[rectangular function]] and <math>\mathrm{tri}(x) \ </math> is the [[triangular function]].
The effective frequency response is the [[continuous Fourier transform]] of the impulse response.
:{| |- |<math>H_{\mathrm{FOH}}(f)\,</math> |<math>= \mathcal{F} \{ h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t) \} \ </math> |- | |<math>= (1 + i 2\pi fT) \left( \frac{1 - e^{-i 2\pi fT}}{i 2\pi fT} \right)^2 \ </math> |- | |<math>= (1 + i 2\pi fT) e^{-i 2\pi fT} \mathrm{sinc}^2(fT)) \ </math> |}
: where <math>\mathrm{sinc}(x) \ </math> is the [[sinc function]].
The [[Laplace transform]] [[transfer function]] of the predictive FOH is found by substituting ''s'' = ''i'' 2 π ''f'':
:{| |- |<math>H_{\mathrm{FOH}}(s)\,</math> |<math>= \mathcal{L} \{ h_{\mathrm{FOH}}(t) \} \ </math> |- | |<math>= (1 + sT) \left( \frac{1 - e^{-sT}}{sT} \right)^2 \ </math> |}
This a [[causal system]]. The impulse response of the predictive FOH does not respond before the input impulse.
This kind of piecewise linear reconstruction is physically realizable by implementing a [[digital filter]] of gain ''H''(''z'') = 1 − ''z''<sup>−1</sup>, applying the output of that digital filter (which is simply ''x''[''n'']−''x''[''n''−1]) to an ideal conventional [[digital-to-analog converter]] (that has an inherent [[zero-order hold]] as its model) and applying that DAC output to an analog filter with transfer function ''H''(''s'') = (1+''sT'')/(''sT'').
==See also== * [[Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem]] * [[Zero-order hold]] *[[Bilinear interpolation]]
==External links== * [http://www.dsplog.com/2007/03/25/zero-order-hold-and-first-order-hold-based-interpolation/ Zero order hold and first order hold based interpolation]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Goop | logo = File:Gooponlinelogo.svg | type = Privately held company | industry = [[Publishing]]
[[Internet retail]]
[[Pseudoscience]] | founder = Gwyneth Paltrow | location = Los Angeles, California, U.S. | key_people = Gwyneth Paltrow, CEO
Elise Loehnen, CCO | foundation = 2008 | homepage = [https://goop.com/ Goop.com] }} {{alternative medical systems}} '''Goop''' (often stylized as '''goop''') is a company owned by actress [[Gwyneth Paltrow]]. It was launched as a "[[lifestyle brand]]" by Paltrow in September 2008, beginning as a weekly e-mail newsletter providing [[new age]] advice, such as "police your thoughts" and "eliminate white foods", and the slogan "Nourish the Inner Aspect".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/22/fashion/22gwyneth.html|title=Martha, Oprah ... Gwyneth?|last=Morris|first=Bob|date=February 22, 2009|work=The New York Times|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} A lifestyle website was later added, and then Goop expanded into [[e-commerce]], collaborating with fashion brands, launching [[pop-up shop]]s,{{cite news|url=https://www.racked.com/2015/7/21/9006055/goop-gwyneth-paltrow|title=Inside Goop, Gwyneth Paltrow's Growing Empire|last1=Lieber|first1=Chavie|date=21 July 2015|work=[[Vox Media|Racked]]}} holding a "wellness summit", and launching a print magazine. Goop has faced criticism for promoting and selling products and treatments that have no scientific basis, lack [[efficacy]], and are recognized by the medical establishment as harmful or as misleading. In 2017, consumer advocacy group [[Truth in Advertising (organization)|Truth in Advertising]] filed a complaint with the government regulatory agency regarding over 50 health claims made by Goop as dangerous and false.{{cite web|title=TINA.org Takes Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop-y Health Claims to Regulators {{!}} Truth In Advertising|url=https://www.truthinadvertising.org/tina-takes-goop-claims-to-regulators/|website=Truth In Advertising|accessdate=24 August 2017|date=22 August 2017}} {{toclimit|limit=3}} ==History== Goop began as a newsletter in 2008,{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-goop-gwyneth-paltrow-20160817-snap-story.html|title=Gwyneth Paltrow's lifestyle business Goop is moving to Los Angeles|date=2016-08-17|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-08-27|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} with an editor's note in each email from Paltrow offering insight into her daily life.{{cite journal |last1=Logan |first1=Dana W. |title=The Lean Closet: Asceticism in Postindustrial Consumer Culture |journal=[[Journal of the American Academy of Religion]] |date=September 2017 |volume=85 |issue=3 |pages=600–628 |doi=10.1093/jaarel/lfw091}} Goop was incorporated in 2011.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapid=256105387|title=Goop Inc. Limited: Private Company Information - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-08-27}} According to Paltrow, the company's name "is a nickname, like my name is G.P., so that is really where it came from. And I wanted it to be a word that means nothing and could mean anything."{{cite web|title=GOOP: It's a portal into Gwyneth Paltrow's life|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2009-01-06-paltrow-goop_N.htm|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=29 July 2017}} [[Seb Bishop]] served as CEO of Goop from 2011 to 2014.{{cite news|url=https://pagesix.com/2014/04/16/gwyneths-goop-ceo-quits-in-corporate-uncoupling/?_ga=1.63963820.2064880802.1392929408|title=Goop CEO quits after Paltrow’s ‘uncoupling’|last1=Smith|first1=Emily|date=17 April 2014|work=[[Page Six]]|accessdate=11 August 2017|language=en}} Several other celebrities were inspired by Goop to launch their own lifestyle websites.{{cite news|last1=Stein|first1=Joshua David|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Inspires Famous Imitators|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/14/fashion/Gwyneth-Paltrows-Goop-inspires-other-celebrity-websites.html|accessdate=12 August 2017|work=The New York Times|date=13 November 2013}} In 2014, Goop hired [[Oxygen Media]] founder and former CEO of [[Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia]] Lisa Gersh as CEO.{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2014/10/06/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-ceo-gersh/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow hires ex-Martha Stewart chief as Goop CEO|last=Sellers|first=Patricia|date=October 5, 2014|work=Fortune|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} From 2014 onwards, Goop's [[Wellness (alternative medicine)|wellness]] content became increasingly radical: to the point where doctors would begin to call it pseudoscience and media outlets would describe Goop's content as "no longer ludicrous — no, now it was dangerous".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/25/magazine/big-business-gwyneth-paltrow-wellness.html|title=How Goop’s Haters Made Gwyneth Paltrow’s Company Worth $250 Million|last=Brodesser-Akner|first=Taffy|date=25 July 2018|work=The New York Times|accessdate=26 July 2018|language=en}} In 2015, Paltrow stated that she wanted goop to "be its own stand-alone brand".{{cite web |title=Gwyneth Paltrow: I Questioned Being Hired as a Face |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-03-06/gwyneth-paltrow-i-questioned-being-hired-as-a-face |website=www.bloomberg.com}} As of 2015, around two dozen people worked for Goop. The company had approximately 60 employees in 2016. In the same year, Goop's most searched topic was "[[Detoxification (alternative medicine)|detox]]". Later in 2016, Paltrow moved the company's operations to Los Angeles from the UK following her separation from Chris Martin{{cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3048346/gwyneth-paltrow-goes-to-market|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Goes To Market|date=3 August 2015|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|accessdate=12 August 2017}} and Gersh left the position of CEO. The position remained vacant until early 2017, when the board named Paltrow - who had previously announced in 2016 that she would be stepping away from Goop{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jul/29/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-separation-news|title=Gwyneth Paltrow plans separation from Goop|last=Shoard|first=Catherine|date=July 29, 2016|work=The Guardian|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} - to fill the post.{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/03/23/gwyneth-paltrow-ceo-goop/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Says She’s Now CEO of Her Lifestyle Brand Goop|last=Zillman|first=Claire|date=March 23, 2017|work=Fortune|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} By 2017, Goop had 90 employees, and was attracting criticism, including a lawsuit filed by Truth In Advertising.{{cite news|url=https://www.girlboss.com/girlboss/gwyneth-paltrow-interview-girlboss-radio|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Speaks Out About All That Goop Controversy|work=Girlboss Media: Redefining success for ourselves.|accessdate=17 December 2017}} In an April 2017 [[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]] article, Stassa Edwards criticized Goop's marketing and retail strategy, claiming that the company profits "from endless illness." [[Jill Avery]], a brand analyst, has noted how Goop's response to criticism seems designed to "strengthen their brand and draw their customers closer", noting Goop's use of [[feminism]], [[traditional Asian medicine]]s and [[Eastern philosophy|Eastern philosophies]], and [[anti-establishment]] politics to do so. Paltrow characterizes criticisms as "cultural firestorms" which cause an influx of website traffic, stating that she can "monetize those eyeballs". In 2018, Goop began assembling an internal science and regulatory team.{{cite web |url=https://goop.com/the-science-regulatory-wellness-portal/ |title=The Science & Regulatory Wellness Portal |last= |first= |date= |website=Goop |access-date=1 December 2018}} Goop in partnership with Google also began selling Google Home [[smart speaker]]s and accessories in the Goop Lab stores and holiday pop-up shops,{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/the-goods/2018/10/17/17990894/goop-google-holiday-pop-up-partnership|title=Why Google wants to sell its gadgets in Goop stores|work=Vox|access-date=2018-10-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.blog.google/products/hardware/new-ways-experience-made-google-products/|title=New ways to experience Made by Google products|date=2018-10-09|work=Google|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}} and opened its first permanent East Coast Goop store called Goop Lab located at 25 [[Bond Street]] in New York. This follows the permanent location they opened in [[Brentwood, Los Angeles|Brentwood]], California in September 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-opens-chic-store-new-york-city-1197092|title=Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop opens insanely chic permanent store in New York City|date=2018-11-01|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en}} == Funding and revenue == In 2011, Goop generated £81,000 in sales, and the year after it generated £1.1 million in sales, with a loss of £23,000. As of 2013, Goop had net liabilities of £540,086.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/aug/02/celebrity-lifestyles-for-sale-gwyneth-paltrow|title=Celebrity lifestyles for sale|last1=Wiseman|first1=Eva|date=2 August 2015|work=The Guardian|accessdate=11 August 2017}} Goop doubled its revenues from 2014 to 2015, and again from 2015 to 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/why-brands-are-clamoring-to-work-with-gwyneth-paltrows-goop/|title=Why Brands Are Clamoring to Work With Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop|access-date=2017-09-24|language=en-US}} In 2016, Goop received $15 million [[USD]] in [[Series B funding]] from venture capital firms NEA, Felix Capital and 14W Venture Partner.{{cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3069237/gwyneth-paltrow-wants-to-put-her-goop-inside-you|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Wants To Put Her Goop Inside You|date=27 March 2017|work=Fast Company|accessdate=24 August 2017}} This corresponded with Goop centralizing their operations in the Los Angeles area, where Paltrow is based, and away from New York, where Gersh lives.{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/08/17/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-series-b/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Takes Her Lifestyle Website ‘Goop’ To The West Coast|last=Farber|first=Madeline|date=August 17, 2016|work=Fortune|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In 2018, Goop raised $50 million in Series C funding from firms including NEA, [[Lightspeed Venture Partners|Lightspeed]] and Felix Capital,{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maddieberg/2018/03/28/exclusive-gwyneth-paltrows-lifestyle-company-goop-raises-50-million-series-c/#50fa8ad96880|title=Exclusive: Gwyneth Paltrow's Lifestyle Company Goop Raises $50 Million Series C|last=Berg|first=Madeline|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en}} bringing total investment in the company to $82 million. The company's valuation rose to $250 million.{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/03/30/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-series-c-valuation-250-million/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow's Company Goop Is Now Valued at $250 Million|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}} == Products and distribution == Goop launched an online shop in 2012, and it earned $1.5 million for Goop during its first year of operation.{{cite news|title=Is Gwyneth Paltrow’s GOOP $1.6M In Debt?|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-16m-debt-1718036|work=International Business Times|date=3 November 2014}} By 2014, the Goop newsletter had an estimated 700,000 subscribers.{{cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/intelligence/gwyneth-paltrows-contextual-commerce-play|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Contextual Commerce Play|date=29 May 2015|work=[[The Business of Fashion]]|accessdate=27 August 2017}} In 2015, Goop launched a publishing imprint, Goop Press, with [[Grand Central Publishing]], and planned to release one title per year.{{cite news|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/68649-gcp-to-launch-paltrow-s-goop-press.html|title=GCP to Launch Paltrow's Goop Press|last1=Deahl|first1=Rachel|date=November 11, 2015|work=[[Publishers Weekly]]|accessdate=15 February 2018|language=en}} In 2016, additional funds also led to an increase in staffing for Goop, as well as the launch of new products, including a fashion label{{Cite news|url=http://wwd.com/business-news/media/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-staffs-up-editorial-director-nandita-khanna-10566137/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Staffs Up, Adds Editorial Director|last=Steigrad|first=Alexandra|date=September 26, 2016|work=Women's Wear Daily|access-date=July 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} with a focus on practical, tailored clothing.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2016/09/gwyneth-paltrow-clothing-line-goop-label|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Clothing Line Has Finally Arrived|last=Duboff|first=Josh|work=Vanities|access-date=2017-08-27|language=en}} In 2017, Goop entered the vitamin and supplements market. Paltrow first had the idea to market [[Dietary supplement|supplements]] after receiving a [[Myers' cocktail]] from Alejandro Junger in 2007.{{Cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/03/27/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-expands-into-vitamins|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Expands Into Vitamins|last=Marikar|first=Sheila|date=March 27, 2017|work=The New Yorker|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The supplements range sold over $100,000 worth of product on the launch day. In April, Goop announced that they had entered into an agreement with [[Condé Nast]] to launch a new print magazine under the name Goop.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/28/fashion/goop-conde-nast-magazine.html|title=Goop and Condé Nast Team Up on a Magazine|last=Safronova|first=Valeriya|date=April 28, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=July 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The quarterly magazine was launched in September,{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2017/09/goop-magazine-gwyneth-paltrow-cover|title=Goop’s First Magazine Cover Star Is . . . Gwyneth Paltrow!|last=Bryant|first=Kenzie|work=Vanities|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en}} but only ran for two issues, with Nast replacing pieces that failed their fact-checking process by travel articles,{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jul/25/gwyneth-paltrow-didnt-want-conde-nast-to-fact-check-goop-articles|title=Gwyneth Paltrow didn't want Condé Nast to fact-check Goop articles|last=Wolfson|first=Sam|date=July 25, 2018|work=The Guardian|access-date=July 26, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726111546/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jul/25/gwyneth-paltrow-didnt-want-conde-nast-to-fact-check-goop-articles?CMP=fb_gu|archive-date=July 26, 2018}} and a disagreement over the use of the magazine to promote Goop products. In December 2017, Goop announced the launch of a digital shop in Canada, following its first physical store in the country in partnership with Nordstrom.{{Cite news|url=http://www.fashion.ie/gwyneth-paltrow-launch-goop-canada/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow to launch Goop in Canada Fashion.ie Fashion news Celebrity Entertainment News|date=2017-12-16|work=Fashion - Irish Fashion News|access-date=2017-12-18|language=en-US}} Goop generates revenue from advertising and also sells a Goop-branded clothing line, a perfume, and books. As of 2017 Goop readers have an average household income of $100k+ per year. Goop launched a [[podcast]] in March 2018 using Cadence13 as its digital platform. Its first guest was [[Oprah Winfrey]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/goop-podcast-gwyneth-paltrow-oprah|title=Goop Has a Podcast—And Oprah Is Its First Guest|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-03-15|language=en}} The podcast reached number one in the Apple Podcast charts on March 8.{{Cite web|url=http://www.itunescharts.net/us/artists/podcast/goop-inc-and-cadence13/podcasts/the-goop-podcast/|title=iTunesCharts.net: 'The goop Podcast' by Goop, Inc. and Cadence13 (American Podcasts iTunes Chart)|website=www.itunescharts.net|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}} It is largely hosted by Goop CCO Elise Loehnen and has a weekly audience of 100,000 to 650,000. The company also partnered with [[Westin Hotels & Resorts]] to offer a range of fitness programs called "G. Sport Sessions" later that summer.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-partnering-westin-hotels-fitness-sessions-1115897|title=Goop Partnering With Westin Hotels on Fitness Sessions|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en}} Goop expanded its fashion offerings in 2018, hiring Danielle Pergament of [[Allure (magazine)|Allure]] to be Goop's editor in chief, directly under CCO Elise Loehnen. Ali Pew of [[InStyle]] was hired as Goop's fashion director and Anne Keane, formerly of [[Lucky magazine]] is now Goop's fashion strategy director, and they will be attending New York Fashion Week as representatives of the company.{{cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/news-bites/goop-hires-editor-in-chief-from-allure|title=Goop Hires Editor-in-Chief from Allure|date=21 February 2018|work=The Business of Fashion|accessdate=26 July 2018}} In June 2018, Goop launched a capsule collection with fashion designer [[Lilly Pulitzer]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.usmagazine.com/stylish/pictures/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-x-lilly-pulitzer-dresses-blouses-bag/gwyneth-stretch-shift-dress/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop x Lilly Pulitzer Dresses, Blouses, Bag|date=2018-06-29|work=Us Weekly|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en-US}} In June 2018, Goop opened its first international pop-up shop in [[London]]. The company also hired its first chief marketing officer, Andres Sosa, to work on further expansion in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/news-bites/goop-hires-first-chief-marketing-officer-from-ynap-as-it-plots-european-expansion|title=Goop Hires First Chief Marketing Officer from YNAP as It Plots European Expansion|date=2018-06-08|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en-GB}} In August 2018, Goop launched a furniture and home decor line with Crate and Barrel's CB2 brand.{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/goop-cb2-furniture-line|title=Goop and CB2 Join Forces for New Furniture Line {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90229535/an-exclusive-first-look-at-goops-debut-furniture-collection|title=An exclusive first look at Goop’s debut furniture collection|date=2018-08-30|work=Fast Company|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-US}} In October 2018, Goop started selling Suzy Batiz's new brand, Supernatural, in the [[Highland Park Village]] pop-up shop and on the Goop website. Batiz explained that she was interested in the partnership after being a panelist at In Goop Health and seeing the brands at the event.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/home-garden/2018/10/supernatural-cleaners-suzy-batiz-poo-pourri-goop/|title=The Poo-Pourri Founder Just Made Cleaning Sexy - D Magazine|date=2018-10-24|work=D Magazine|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en-US}} === Brands and product lines === Since Goop's inception in 2008, it has launched a number of brands and product lines. The "Beauty" section of the website works in tandem with the products sold in the shop. Goop brands and product lines are sold online, at the Goop Lab in Brentwood Country Mart in Los Angeles,{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/home/gwyneth-paltrow-new-goop-store-goop-lab-photos/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Goop Store 'Goop Lab' in Los Angeles|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/22/sex-dust-and-vampire-repellent-a-stroll-through-gwyneth-paltrows-new-la-store|title=Sex Dust and vampire repellent: a stroll through Gwyneth Paltrow's new LA store|last=Carroll|first=Rory|date=2017-09-22|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} and at pop-up shops in Los Angeles,{{Cite news|url=https://fashionista.com/2017/09/goop-gwyneth-paltrow-store|title=With Its First Permanent Store, Goop Gives Shoppers a Taste of Gwyneth Paltrow's Own Home|work=Fashionista|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}} {{unreliable source?|date=January 2018}} New York,{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/blog/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-now-has-a-pop-up-in-nyc-and-its-ridiculous-111717|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s goop now has a pop-up in NYC and it’s ridiculous|work=[[Time Out New York]]|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}} Chicago, the Hamptons,{{Cite news|url=http://wwd.com/eye/lifestyle/goop-launches-first-pop-up-store-in-the-hamptons-10924188/|title=Goop Launches First Pop-up Store in the Hamptons|last=Nordstrom|first=Leigh|date=2017-06-22|work=[[Women's Wear Daily]]|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}} [[Dallas]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.papercitymag.com/fashion/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-opening-new-store-dallas-highland-park-village/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop is Opening a New Store in Dallas: This Time, It's Much More Goop-y {{!}} PaperCity Magazine|date=2018-02-20|work=PaperCity Magazine|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en-US}} and [[Aspen, Colorado|Aspen]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2018/06/11/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-opens-aspen/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop opens Aspen pop-up|date=2018-06-11|work=The Denver Post|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en-US}} and in collaboration with [[Nordstrom]] stores.{{Cite news|url=http://www.instyle.com/celebrity/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-nordstrom-pop-up-shop|title=Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop Teams Up with Nordstrom for New Pop-Up Shops|work=[[InStyle.com]]|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}} Goop-branded products quadrupled in value in 2017. These brands include: *'''goop by Juice Beauty''', a makeup and skincare line launched in partnership with [[Juice Beauty]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3048466/why-gwyneth-paltrow-chose-juice-beauty-to-power-her-new-skincare-line|title=Why Gwyneth Paltrow Chose Juice Beauty To Power Goop’s New Skin-Care Line|date=2015-08-03|work=Fast Company|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}} in 2016, influenced by the popularity of a Goop article the year before about beauty products without formaldehyde and endocrine disruptors. The brand's products are made from USDA certified organic ingredients and are considered to be vegan.{{Cite news|url=https://www.shape.com/lifestyle/beauty-style/gwyneth-paltrow-introduces-goop-juice-beauty-skincare-line|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Introduces GOOP by Juice Beauty Skin Care Line|date=2016-03-07|work=[[Shape Magazine]]|access-date=2018-01-01}} *'''goop Label''', a fashion line launched in September 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3063676/the-goop-est-thing-about-gwyneth-paltrows-new-clothing-line-isnt-the-clothes|title=The Goop-est Thing About Gwyneth Paltrow’s New Clothing Line Isn’t The Clothes|date=2016-09-13|work=Fast Company|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}} The collection is based on Paltrow's personal favorites and styles,{{Cite news|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/designers/news/a18170/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-label/|title=Exclusive: See Gwyneth Paltrow's New Fashion Line|date=2016-10-10|work=[[Harper's BAZAAR]]|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}} and has been described as "[[High Street chic|high-street]] staples".{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/sep/13/goop-label-gwyneth-paltrow-fashion-line|title=Goop Label: what is Gwyneth Paltrow's fashion line like?|last=Elan|first=Priya|date=2016-09-13|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} *'''goop Fragrance''', an all-natural fragrance line including perfume and scented candles.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/gwyneth-paltrows-first-goop-fragrance|title=Gwyneth Paltrow's First Goop Fragrance|last=Moulton|first=Nicola|access-date=2018-01-01}} The first fragrance, Edition 01 Winter, was created by the [[perfumer]] Douglas Little{{Cite news|url=http://www.elle.com/beauty/news/a40425/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-fragrance-launch/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Wants You to Smell Like Winter|date=2016-11-02|work=ELLE|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}} and released in November 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2016/11/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-fragrance-edition-01|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Surprise-Drops Her First Fragrance|last=Blasberg|first=Derek|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanities]]|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}} *'''goop Wellness''', which sells GMO and gluten-free{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/03/are-nutritional-supplements-good-for-you-goop-says-yes.html|title=Will Goop’s New Vitamins Save Us All?|last=Hou|first=Kathleen|work=[[New York (magazine)|The Cut]]|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}} vitamins and other supplements. The line was launched in 2017,{{Cite news|url=http://jezebel.com/wellness-womanhood-and-the-west-how-goop-profits-fro-1793674265|title=Wellness, Womanhood, and the West: How Goop Profits From Endless Illness|last=Edwards|first=Stassa|date=April 28, 2017|work=Jezebel|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} and was influenced by the popularity of a Goop article that year about "postnatal depletion". *'''G. Sport Sessions,''' a range of fitness programs offered in partnership with Westin Hotels and Resorts launched in 2018, with classes led by [[Tracy Anderson]], Paltrow's personal trainer. *'''cb2 x goop,''' a furniture and home décor line in collaboration with Crate and Barrel, launched in August 2018. == Wellness summits == Goop held its first wellness summit in June 2017. The event had over 600 attendees.{{cite web|url=http://people.com/bodies/in-goop-health-gwyneth-paltrow-wellness-summit/|title=We Attended Gwyneth Paltrow's $500-a-Ticket Health Summit: These Are the Craziest Things We Witnessed|date=12 June 2017|publisher=[[People.com]]}} The company's second In goop Health summit in New York City in January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/style-notes-rocks-new-under-armour-collection-honors-military-goop-summit-speakers-announced-1056722|title=Style Notes: The Rock's New Under Armour Collection Honors Military; Goop Summit Speakers Announced|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-summit-new-york|title=You Can Try Magnetic Acupressure With Gwyneth Paltrow In New York This Winter|last=Abouarrage|first=Nada|work=W Magazine|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}} Celebrity guests and speakers included [[Drew Barrymore]], [[Chelsea Handler]] and [[Laura Linney]].{{Cite news|url=https://pagesix.com/2018/01/27/health-nuts-spend-hundreds-at-goops-wild-health-summit/|title=Health nuts spend hundreds at Goop’s wild health summit|date=2018-01-28|work=Page Six|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en-US}} Panelists included Kelly Brogan, a "holistic health psychiatrist", who has disputed the effectiveness of both vaccinations and HIV medications. The invitation of Brogan has been criticized by ''Page Six'' and ''Jezebel''.{{cite news|url=https://jezebel.com/anti-medication-goop-summit-expert-claims-aids-treatmen-1820919802|title=Anti-Medication Goop Summit Expert Claims AIDS Treatment Kills and GMOs Cause Depression|last1=Rothkopf|first1=Joanna|work=Jezebel|accessdate=17 December 2017}} The third summit was held in [[Culver City, California]] in June 2018. Guests included [[Meg Ryan]] and [[Janet Mock]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2018/06/10/gwyneth-paltrow-defies-critics-expands-goop-health-summit/688785002/|title=Gwyneth Paltrow brings aerial yoga, trans talks and cryofacials to Goop health conference|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en}} Paltrow is considering ways to take the wellness summit "on the road", so that it can access a wider audience. In October 2018, Goop held its fourth summit at the [[Stanley Park]] pavilion in [[Vancouver]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.straight.com/life/1148056/goop-extends-wellness-summit-vancouver-after-stunningly-selling-out-first-day-events|title=Goop extends wellness summit in Vancouver after, astonishingly, selling out first day of events|date=2018-10-09|work=Georgia Straight Vancouver's News & Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/goop-ies-flock-to-gwyneth-paltrow-s-wellness-summit-in-vancouver-amid-critiques-of-company-1.4881907|title='Goop-ies' flock to Gwyneth Paltrow's wellness summit in Vancouver amid critiques of company {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} ==Parodies== In December 2016 a book parodying Goop called ''Glop: Nontoxic Ideas That Will Make You Look Ridiculous and Feel Pretentious'' was published and included advice like, "Our modern lifestyles are absolutely full of toxins — nearly everything we come into daily contact with, from Egyptian cotton sheets to 8-carat diamonds to yacht paint, is dangerously noxious."{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Jaleesa M. |title=10 commandments from Goop parody book, 'Glop' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2016/12/27/glop-goop-parody-book/95861040/ |work=USA TODAY |date=December 27, 2016 |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Reed |first1=Sam |title=This Goop Parody Is Scary Similar to the Real Thing |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/goop-parody-is-scary-similar-real-thing-944762 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=November 7, 2016 |language=en}} By June 2017 the ''New York Times'' reported that parodying Goop had "become a national pastime".{{cite news |last1=Jacobs |first1=Alexandra |title=Meet the Goopies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/14/fashion/gwyneth-paltrow-in-goop-health-wellness.html |work=New York Times |date=June 14, 2017 |language=en}} Paltrow appeared on The Late Show in 2018 in a spoof segment announcing a collaboration between Goop and Stephen Colbert's lifestyle brand, Covetton House, featuring a sponge which cost $900. Later that year, Colbert and Paltrow collaborated on a line of goods to raise money for education in the United States.{{cite news |title=Gwyneth Paltrow and Stephen Colbert Are Selling Goop-Like Products to Raise Money for Public Schools |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/gwyneth-paltrow-stephen-colbert-are-selling-goop-like-products-raise-money-public-schools-1104064 |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=19 April 2018 |language=en}} In March 2018 [[Botnik Studios]] created a newsletter called "goob" parodying Goop, which generated text using [[predictive text]]; headlines included "Listen to Your Body: Your Migraines are Podcasts Trying to be Produced".{{cite news |last1=Sung |first1=Morgan |title=Predictive text helped make a pretty great Gwenyth Paltrow Goop parody |url=https://mashable.com/2018/03/02/goop-parody-predictive-text-gwenyth-paltrow-botnik-studios/#P32.X_WDYaqI |work=Mashable |date=March 2, 2018 |language=en}} A performance artist sold "Hot Dog Water" outside the fourth In Goop Health summit, a bottle of water with a hotdog inside, which parodied a product sold on Goop with a crystal inside a bottle of water. == Criticism == Goop has been criticized for showcasing expensive products and making "out of touch" recommendations that many readers cannot afford,{{cite news|title=Leave Gwyneth Paltrow alone! Her website gives me joy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/mar/23/gwyneth-paltrow-is-an-ethereal-being-not-of-this-world-thats-why-i-love-her|work=The Guardian|date=23 March 2015}} which Paltrow has responded to by stating that such products and recommendations are "aspirational",{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Julie|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Responds to Claims That Goop is Out of Touch|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/03/gwyneth-paltrow-goop|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|language=en}} furthermore arguing that the items available cannot be made for a lower [[price point]], and that the content of Goop is free. Dana Logan argues that Goop is an example of [[asceticism]] as part of consumer culture. Goop has also drawn criticism for selling [[Ingredients of cosmetics|cosmetics containing the same ostensibly harmful chemicals]] which the site tells people to avoid.{{cite news|last1=Senapathy|first1=Kavin|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Sells 'Toxic' Goop With Ingredients She Says Are Dangerous|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kavinsenapathy/2016/07/21/gwyneth-paltrow-sells-toxic-goop/#79cd53e37ec3|work=Forbes|date=July 21, 2016|language=en}} In April 2015, Paltrow and the Goop staff participated in a [[food stamp challenge]] in an attempt to demonstrate that her readers could abide by her dietary recommendations despite living on food stamps.{{Cite web|url=http://goop.com/my-29-food-stamp-challenge-and-the-recipes-brouhaha-that-ensued/|title=My $29 Food Stamp Challenge—and the Recipes (& Brouhaha) That Ensued|last=Paltrow|first=Gwyneth|date=2015-04-16|website=Goop|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}} Critics suggested that people on food stamps could not afford Paltrow's recommendations,{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/apr/15/gwyneth-paltrow-food-banks-snap|title=Dear Gwyneth, this is what living on food stamps really looks like|last=Kasperkevic|first=Jana|date=April 15, 2015|work=The Guardian|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} and Paltrow gave up on the challenge after four days.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/04/17/a-hungry-gwyneth-paltrow-fails-the-food-stamp-challenge-four-days-in/|title=A hungry Gwyneth Paltrow fails the food-stamp challenge four days in|last=Bever|first=Lindsey|date=April 17, 2015|work=The Washington Post|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} A number of products sold by Goop, as well as ideas promoted in its [[blog]] posts, have been criticized for having no scientific basis, not producing the desired results, having no medical benefit, or potentially even being harmful: *In January 2015, Paltrow advocated for a spa treatment referred to as [[vaginal steaming]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-beauty/news/gwyneth-paltrow-gets-vagina-steam-at-spa-preaches-its-virtues-on-goop-2015291|title=Gwyneth Paltrow Gets Vagina Steam at Spa, Preaches Its Virtues on Goop|last=|first=|date=January 29, 2015|work=US Magazine|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} a process she reportedly underwent at the Tikkun Spa in the [[Los Angeles]] area, wherein "you sit on what is essentially a mini-throne, and a combination of [[infrared]] and [[mugwort]] steam cleanses your uterus, et al."{{Cite web|url=http://goop.com/city-guide/infrared-saunas-detox-spas-and-the-best-spots-for-colonics/los-angeles/|title=Infrared Saunas, Detox Spas, and the Best Spots for Colonics|last=|first=|date=|website=Goop|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}} Paltrow admitted that she thought that the process was "insane" but did not disavow it, instead suggesting that it has "real healing properties."{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/swellness/2016/07/gwyneth-paltrow-on-wellness-and-natural-beauty-yoga.html|title=Gwyneth Paltrow on Wellness and Vaginal Steaming|last=Hou|first=Kathleen|date=July 18, 2016|work=The Cut|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} [[Gynecologists]] were critical, with Draion Burch, an obstetrics and gynaecology specialist, indicating that "there's no scientific evidence that shows it works."{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/49648-vaginal-steaming-no-benefits.html|title=No, Gwyneth Paltrow, Vaginas Don't Need to Be Steam Cleaned|last=Ghose|first=Tia|date=January 30, 2015|work=Live Science|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} An article published on July 18, 2017 in [[Toronto Star|TheStar.com]] documented the ongoing battle over this issue between Paltrow and [[Jennifer Gunter]], an [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|OB/GYN]] for [[Kaiser Permanente]] in [[San Francisco]], whom the ''Toronto Star'' dubbed an expert in "vaginal health." {{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/life/2017/07/18/meet-the-canadian-doctor-whos-taking-on-goop.html|title=This Canadian doctor is going head-to-head with Gwyneth Paltrow over Goop|last1=McKnight|first1=Zoe|website=Thestar.com|publisher=Toronto Star|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170805184336/https://www.thestar.com/life/2017/07/18/meet-the-canadian-doctor-whos-taking-on-goop.html|archivedate=5 August 2017|dead-url=no|accessdate=5 August 2017}} Also in 2015, [[Timothy Caulfield]] wrote a book on the negative impact of celebrity endorsement called "Is Gwyneth Paltrow Wrong About Everything?" in which he described the lack of evidence for several products sold by Goop and [[celebrity endorsement|endorsed]] by Paltrow, as well as health claims made by other celebrities.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/11591936/Is-Gwyneth-Paltrow-wrong-about-everything.html|title=Is Gwyneth Paltrow wrong about everything?|last=Walden|first=Celia|date=May 9, 2015|work=The Telegraph|access-date=November 26, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171126175648/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/11591936/Is-Gwyneth-Paltrow-wrong-about-everything.html|archive-date=November 26, 2017|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/sorry-gwyneth-paltrow-science-will-always-beat-goopy-junk/article35696259/|title=Sorry, Gwyneth Paltrow. Science will always beat goopy junk|last=Caulfield|first=Timothy|authorlink=Timothy Caulfield|date=July 14, 2017|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=November 26, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171126175832/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/sorry-gwyneth-paltrow-science-will-always-beat-goopy-junk/article35696259/|archive-date=November 26, 2017|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.allure.com/story/book-is-gwyneth-wrong-about-everything|title=This New Book Asks, Is Gwyneth Paltrow Wrong About Everything?|last=Atterton|first=Kelly|date=May 22, 2015|work=Allure|access-date=December 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205223737/https://www.allure.com/story/book-is-gwyneth-wrong-about-everything|archive-date=December 5, 2017|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2017/7/19/15988180/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-jade-egg-debunkers|title=Is Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop pseudoscience winning?|last=Belluz|first=Julia|authorlink=Julia Belluz|date=September 12, 2017|work=[[Vox.com]]|access-date=December 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171205223848/https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2017/7/19/15988180/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-jade-egg-debunkers|archive-date=December 5, 2017|dead-url=no}} *In October 2015, in a blog post in Goop, Habib Sadeghi revisited the disproven claim that [[breast cancer]] might be linked to wearing [[underwire bra]]s. The claim was swiftly criticized,{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/gwyneth-paltrow-bras-breast-cancer_us_56266d6de4b0bce34702523c|title=Gwyneth Paltrow’s Blog Resurrects Discredited Breast Cancer Myth|last=Jeltsen|first=Melissa|date=October 23, 2015|work=HuffPost|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} with Gunter stating "it’s breast size that increases the risk of breast cancer and not because larger breasts need more manhandling by underwires, but because larger breasts are harder to screen and are associated with obesity, a known risk for breast cancer."{{Cite web|url=https://drjengunter.wordpress.com/2015/10/20/hey-gwyneth-paltrow-a-gyn-says-stop-scaring-women-about-bras-and-breast-cancer/|title=Hey Gwyneth Paltrow, a GYN says stop scaring women about bras and breast cancer|last=Gunter|first=Jen|author-link=Jennifer Gunter|date=October 20, 2015|website=Dr. Jen Gunter|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2015}} *In January 2017, Goop marketed the "Jade Egg" for $66.00 [[United States dollar|USD]] as a form of [[vaginal weightlifting]] which, according to their website, is "used by women to increase sexual energy, health, and pleasure."{{Cite web|url=https://shop.goop.com/shop/products/jade-egg|title=Jade Egg|last=|first=|date=|website=Goop|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}} Again, gynecologists were critical of this product,{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2017/01/22/no-gwyneth-paltrow-women-should-not-put-jade-eggs-in-their-vaginas-gynecologist-says/|title=No, Gwyneth Paltrow, women should not put jade eggs in their vaginas, gynecologist says|last=Phillips|first=Kristine|date=January 22, 2017|work=The Washington Post|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} with Gunter calling it a "load of garbage."{{Cite web|url=https://drjengunter.wordpress.com/2017/01/17/dear-gwyneth-paltrow-im-a-gyn-and-your-vaginal-jade-eggs-are-a-bad-idea/|title=Dear Gwyneth Paltrow, I'm a GYN and your vaginal jade eggs are a bad idea|last=Gunter|first=Jen|author-link =Jennifer Gunter|date=January 17, 2017|website=Dr. Jen Gunter|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}} In 2018, this post was tagged as an "Ancient Modality".{{cite web |title=Gwyneth Paltrow and GOOP say the joke is on you if you followed their advice |url=https://drjengunter.wordpress.com/2018/06/16/goop-is-gas-lighting-women/ |website=Dr. Jen Gunter |accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=16 June 2018}} In September 2018 the Goop company agreed to pay $145,000 to settle a lawsuit alleging that Goop has posted claims about the eggs and about a herbal remedy, both without scientific basis.[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/sep/05/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-to-pay-out-over-unproven-health-benefits-of-vaginal-eggs Goop to pay out over unproven health benefits of vaginal eggs] ''[[The Guardian]]'' *In June 2017, a Goop blog post promoted Body Vibes, wearable stickers that "re-balance the energy frequency in our bodies".{{Cite web|url=http://goop.com/wearable-stickers-that-promote-healing-really/|title=Wearable Stickers that Promote Healing (Really!)|last=|first=|date=2017-06-20|website=Goop|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}} Originally, the advertisement claimed that the stickers were "made with the same conductive carbon material [[NASA]] uses to line space suits so they can monitor an astronaut’s vitals during wear", but NASA denied that they had "any conductive carbon material lining" their spacesuits, with Mark Shelhamer, former chief scientist at NASA's human research division, going so far as to call the claim a "load of BS." The reference to NASA was subsequently removed from the advertisement, with the manufacturer of the stickers issuing a statement to [[Gizmodo]] saying "We apologize to NASA, Goop, our customers and our fans for this communication error. We never intended to mislead anyone. We have learned that our engineer was misinformed by a distributor about the material in question, which was purchased for its unique specifications."{{Cite news|url=https://gizmodo.com/nasa-calls-bullshit-on-goops-120-bio-frequency-healing-1796309360|title=NASA Calls Bullshit on Goop's $120 'Bio-Frequency Healing' Sticker Packs|last=Paoletta|first=Rae|date=June 22, 2017|work=Gizmodo|access-date=July 7, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} *In October 2017, [[The Skeptic (UK magazine)|''The Skeptic'']] awarded Goop the Rusty Razor award "for the most audacious pseudo-science." The award was decided by readers’ votes, and Goop was the winner "by a landslide."[https://www.skeptic.org.uk/ockham-awards-2017/vote/ Ockham awards for excellence in skeptical activism.] Skeptic 2017. *In 2017, Goop promoted a [[coffee enema]] device from Implant O’Rama LLC, despite a lack of scientific evidence to their efficacy and in spite of evidence of coffee enemas' potential dangerous results ranging from infection to death.{{cite news |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/01/gwyneth-paltrows-goop-wants-you-to-start-2018-right-with-a-135-coffee-enema/ |title=In "triumph of ignorance," Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop touts $135 coffee enema |date=January 6, 2018 |access-date=January 7, 2018 |first=Beth |last=Mole |publisher=''[[Ars Technica]]''}}{{cite journal|last1=Ernst|first1=E|authorlink=Edzard Ernst|title=Colonic irrigation and the theory of autointoxication: a triumph of ignorance over science.|journal=Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology|date=June 1997|volume=24|issue=4|pages=196–8|pmid=9252839|url=http://journals.lww.com/jcge/Fulltext/1997/06000/Colonic_Irrigation_and_the_Theory_of.2.aspx}} *In January 2018, Goop was criticized for posting articles by "medical medium" Anthony William who claims to use [[paranormal]] abilities to give advice.{{cite web|last1=Paoletta|first1=Rae|title=Goop's "Trusted Expert" Anthony William Dispenses Junk Science, Say Critics|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/40096-medical-medium-anthony-william|website=Inverse.com|publisher=Inverse|accessdate=30 April 2018|date=10 January 2018}} Goop has said of Williams, that he: {{Quote|text=...is one of the most unconventional and surprisingly insightful healers today: As he explains, the voice of a divine force called Spirit guides him to identify the roots of his patients’ hard-to-diagnose illnesses and find the best solutions to restore their health... Now, William is sharing four of his wonder foods—apples, celery, ginger, and honey—with us. Below, he breaks down what makes them so powerful... which ailments (from anxiety to Lyme disease, adrenal fatigue, and brain fog) to target with each food...}} ===Disclaimers=== Despite routinely posting articles which purport to give health and nutrition advice on a wide range of topics, these articles typically end with this disclaimer: {{Quote|text="The views expressed in this article intend to highlight alternative studies and induce conversation. They are the views of the author and do not necessarily represent the views of Goop, and are for informational purposes only, even if and to the extent that this article features the advice of physicians and medical practitioners. This article is not, nor is it intended to be, a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment, and should never be relied upon for specific medical advice."{{cite web|title=Spirit Says: Healing Foods|url=https://goop.com/wellness/spirituality/healing-food-from-the-medical-medium/|website=goop.com/|publisher=Goop|accessdate=30 April 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.is/APk3Q|archivedate=30 April 2018|date=2016-10-27}}}} In early 2018 Goop started labeling articles with disclaimers indicating whether their content is "For Your Enjoyment" or "Supported by Science".{{cite news |title=Goop Slammed for New Answer to "Deceptive" Advertising Claims |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/goop-slammed-new-answer-deceptive-advertising-claims-1124826 |work=Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=3 July 2018}} In response, on June 29, 2018 the watchdog group Truth in Advertising sent a letter to the California Food Drug and Medical Device Task Force, saying that {{Quote|text=[The disclaimers] make clear that the company is aware that it does not have the appropriate scientific evidence to support many of the health claims that it is making in its marketing materials. Further, as a matter of law, these four disclosures cannot be used as cover for unsubstantiated disease-treatment claims. That is to say, Goop is not permitted to make a deceptive health claim and then post a disclaimer saying, 'sorry, there isn’t reliable and competent scientific evidence to actually support that claim but buy our product to treat your [fill in the ailment] anyway.'{{cite web |title=Amid Goop's Mixed Signals, TINA.org Repeats Call for Regulatory Action |url=https://www.truthinadvertising.org/amid-goops-mixed-signals-tina-org-repeats-call-for-regulatory-action/ |website=Truth in Advertising|accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=3 July 2018}}}} Labels and website descriptions of dietary supplement products required to include the standard wording for the U.S. Food and Drug Administration disclaimer: "These statements have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease." Printing this disclaimer on labels and website does not permit health claims beyond the very basic Structure:Function vocabulary regardless of how strong any clinical trail evidence is.{{cite web |url=https://www.fda.gov/Food/DietarySupplements/IndustryInfo/ucm485532.htm |title=Structure/Function Claim Notification for Dietary Supplements |last= |first= |date= |website=U.S. Food and Drug Administration |access-date=2 December 2018}} ===Legal settlements=== In 2016 Goop said it would voluntarily, permanently discontinue claims for Moon Juice ‘Brain Dust’ and ‘Action Dust’ following an inquiry from the [[Better Business Bureau#National Advertising Division|National Advertising Division]] of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.{{cite web|url=http://www.asrcreviews.org/lifestyle-site-goop-says-it-will-voluntarily-permanently-discontinue-claims-for-moon-juice-brain-dust-action-dust-following-nad-inquiry/|title=Lifestyle Site 'Goop' Says it Will Voluntarily, Permanently Discontinue Claims for Moon Juice 'Brain Dust,' 'Action Dust' Following NAD Inquiry - Advertising Self-Regulation Council|website=www.asrcreviews.org}} On September 4, 2018, [[Bloomberg News]] reported that: "Goop Inc., the lifestyle company founded by Oscar-winning actress Gwyneth Paltrow, agreed to pay $145,000 to settle allegations it made unscientific claims about the benefits of three products." Two of the products were 'vaginal eggs' and the third was Inner Judge Flower Essence Blend. To settle this California case, Goop also agreed to refund money to customers and stop making health claims for those products.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-05/gwyneth-paltrow-s-goop-settles-claims-over-vaginal-egg-benefits |title=Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop Pays $145,000 Over Jade Vaginal-Egg Claims |last=Palmeri |first=C |date=4 September 2018 |website=Bloomberg |access-date=4 September 2018}}{{cite web | url=https://people.com/health/gwyneth-paltrow-goop-pay-settlement-misleading-claims-vaginal-eggs/ | title=Goop to Pay $145,000 Settlement for 'Misleading' Claims About the Effectiveness of Vaginal Eggs}} At the time of the settlement, Goop had sold around 3,000 vaginal eggs.{{cite news |last1=Garcia |first1=Sandra E. |title=Goop Agrees to Pay $145,000 for ‘Unsubstantiated’ Claims About Vaginal Eggs |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/05/business/goop-vaginal-egg-settlement.html |accessdate=23 September 2018 |work=The New York Times |language=en}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Advance Publications}} [[Category:Privately held companies of the United States]] [[Category:American companies established in 2008]] [[Category:Pseudoscience]] [[Category:Health fraud]] [[Category:Alternative detoxification]]

{{Infobox astronomical survey}} The '''Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey''', or '''GOODS''', is an [[astronomical survey]] combining deep observations from three of [[NASA]]'s [[Great Observatories program|Great Observatories]]: the [[Hubble Space Telescope]], the [[Spitzer Space Telescope]], and the [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]], along with data from other [[Space observatory|space-based telescopes]], such as [[XMM Newton]], and some of the world's most powerful ground-based telescopes.
GOODS is intended to enable astronomers to study the [[galaxy formation and evolution|formation and evolution of galaxies]] in the distant, early universe.
[[File:Galaxy history revealed by the Hubble Space Telescope (GOODS-ERS2).jpg|thumb|center|600px|GOODS Field (Hubble component)]]
The Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey consists of optical and near-infrared imaging taken with the [[Advanced Camera for Surveys]] on the [[Hubble Space Telescope]], the [[Very Large Telescope]] and the 4-m telescope at [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]]; [[infrared]] data from the [[Spitzer Space Telescope]]. These are added to pre-existing x-ray data from the [[Chandra X-ray Observatory]] and [[ESA]]s [[XMM-Newton]], two fields of 10' by 16'; one centered on the [[Hubble Deep Field]] North (12h 36m 55s, +62° 14m 15s) and the other on the [[Chandra Deep Field South]] (3h 32m 30s, -27° 48m 20s).
The two GOODS fields are the most data-rich areas of the sky in terms of depth and wavelength coverage.
==Instruments== [[File:GOODS-South field.jpg|thumb|Composite image of the GOODS-South field, result of a deep survey using two of the four giant 8.2-metre telescopes composing [[ESO]]'s [[Very Large Telescope]]]]
GOODS consists of data from the following space-based observatories: *The [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (optical imaging with the [[Advanced Camera for Surveys]]) *The [[Spitzer Space Telescope]] ([[infrared]] imaging) *The [[Chandra X-Ray Observatory]] ([[X-ray]]) *[[XMM-Newton]] (an X-ray telescope belonging to the [[European Space Agency]]) *The [[Herschel Space Observatory]] (an infrared telescope belonging to the ESA)
==Hubble Space Telescope images== GOODs used the [[Hubble Space Telescope]]'s [[Advanced Camera for Surveys]] with four filters, centered at 435, 606, 775 and 850 nm. The resulting map covers 30 times the area of the [[Hubble Deep Field]] to a photometric magnitude less sensitivity, and has enough resolution to allow the study of 1 [[parsec|kpc]]-scale objects at redshifts up to 6. It also provides photometric redshifts for over 60,000 galaxies within the field, providing an excellent sample for studying bright galaxies at high redshifts.<ref name="Beckwith2006">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1086/379232 | last = Giavalisco | first = M. | display-authors=etal | date = 2004 | title = The Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey: Initial Results from Optical and Near-Infrared Imaging | bibcode = 2004ApJ...600L..93G | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 600 | issue = 2 | pages = 93–98 |arxiv = astro-ph/0309105 }}</ref>
==Herschel== In May 2010, scientists announced that the [[infrared]] data from the [[Herschel Space Observatory]] was joining the GOODS dataset, after initial analysis of data using Herschel's [[Herschel Space Observatory#Instrumentation|PACS and SPIRE]] instruments. In October 2009, Herschel observed the GOODS-North field, and in January 2010 the GOODS-South field. In so doing, Herschel identified sources for the [[Cosmic infrared background|Cosmic Infrared Background]].<ref>[http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Herschel_Reveals_Galaxies_In_The_Goods_Fields_In_A_Brand_New_Light_999.html Herschel Reveals Galaxies In The GOODS Fields In A Brand New Light], spacedaily.com, 12 May 2009, accessed 13 May 2009</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:GOODS-South Hubble Deep UV Legacy Field.jpg|Hubble Deep UV (HDUV) Legacy Field, the GOODS-South view.<ref>{{cite web |title=GOODS-South Hubble Deep UV Legacy Field |url=http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/potw1835a/ |website=www.spacetelescope.org |accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> File:Hubble contributes to painting a picture of the evolving Universe GOODS North Field.jpg|GOODS North field taken by [[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Hubble contributes to painting a picture of the evolving Universe |url=http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/potw1834a/ |website=www.spacetelescope.org |accessdate=20 August 2018}}</ref> File:GOODS field containing distant dwarf galaxies forming stars at an incredible rate.jpg|GOODS field containing distant dwarf galaxies<ref>{{cite news|title=Small but significant|url=http://www.spacetelescope.org/news/heic1412/|accessdate=19 June 2014|work=ESA/Hubble Press Release}}</ref> File:GOODS South Field.jpg|GOODS South Field<ref>{{cite news|title=Hubble Uncovers Tiny Galaxies Bursting with Starbirth in Early Universe|url=http://www.spacetelescope.org/news/heic1117/|accessdate=14 November 2011|newspaper=ESA/Hubble Press Release}}</ref> File:NTTDF-474.jpg|Galaxy NTTDF-474 is one of five that have been used to chart the timeline of the reionisation of the Universe.<ref name=eso1138>{{cite news|title=Distant Galaxies Reveal The Clearing of the Cosmic Fog|url=http://www.eso.org/public/news/eso1138/|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=ESO Science Release}}</ref> Image taken by [[ESO]]'s [[Very Large Telescope]]. File:NTTDF-6345.jpg|Galaxy NTTDF-6345 is one of five that have been used to chart the timeline of the reionisation of the Universe.<ref name=eso1138 /> Image taken by [[ESO]]'s [[Very Large Telescope]]. </gallery>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.stsci.edu/science/goods/}} * {{cite web |publisher= [[NASA]] |work= Image of the Day Gallery |date= Jan 7, 2010 |url= http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/imagegallery/image_1558.html |title= History Revealed |quote= More than 12 billion years of cosmic history are shown in this panoramic, full-color view of thousands of galaxies }} * {{cite web |url= http://www.eso.org/public/videos/esocast21/ |publisher= [[ESO]] |work= ESOcast |id= 21 |title= The Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey (GOODS) |date= Sep 27, 2010 }}

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

page.title: Independent and identically distributed random variables

revision.text:
{{Redirect2|IID|iid}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}}
In [[probability theory]] and [[statistics]], a [[sequence]] or collection of [[random variable]]s is '''independent and identically distributed''' (''i.i.d.'' or ''iid'' or '''IID''') if each random variable has the same [[probability distribution]] as the others and all are mutually [[independence (probability theory)|independent]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://tuvalu.santafe.edu/~aaronc/courses/7000/csci7000-001_2011_L0.pdf | title = A brief primer on probability distributions | author = Aaron Clauset | publisher = [[Santa Fe Institute]]}}</ref> Identically distributed, on its own, is often abbreviated '''ID'''. For uniformity, as both are discussed—and in widespread use—this article uses the visually cleaner IID in preference to the more prevalent convention ''i.i.d.''
The annotation IID is particularly common in [[statistics]], where observations in a [[statistical sample|sample]] are often assumed to be effectively IID for the purposes of [[statistical inference]]. The assumption (or requirement) that observations be IID tends to simplify the underlying mathematics of many statistical methods (see [[mathematical statistics]] and [[statistical theory]]). However, in practical applications of [[statistical modeling]] the assumption may or may not be realistic. To test how realistic the assumption is on a given data set, the [[autocorrelation]] can be computed, [[lag plot]]s drawn or [[turning point test]] performed.<ref>{{cite book | title = Performance Evaluation Of Computer And Communication Systems | first = Jean-Yves | last = Le Boudec | isbn = 978-2-940222-40-7 | year=2010 | publisher =[[EPFL Press]]| url = http://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/146812/files/perfPublisherVersion.pdf |pages=46-47}}</ref> The generalization of [[exchangeable random variables]] is often sufficient and more easily met.
The assumption is important in the classical form of the [[central limit theorem]], which states that the probability distribution of the sum (or average) of IID variables with finite [[variance]] approaches a [[normal distribution]].
Often the IID assumption arises in the context of sequences of random variables. Then "independent and identically distributed" in part implies that an element in the sequence is independent of the random variables that came before it. In this way, an IID sequence is different from a [[Markov sequence]], where the probability distribution for the ''n''th random variable is a function of the previous random variable in the sequence (for a first order Markov sequence). An IID sequence does not imply the probabilities for all elements of the [[sample space]] or event space must be the same.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cover|first=Thomas|title=Elements Of Information Theory|year=2006|publisher=Wiley-Interscience|isbn=978-0-471-24195-9|pages=57–58}}</ref> For example, repeated throws of loaded dice will produce a sequence that is IID, despite the outcomes being biased.
==Definition==
Let the random variables be defined to assume values in <math>\mathbb{I} \subseteq \mathbb{R}</math>.
We say two random variables <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are '''identically distributed''' ''[[iff|iff]]'' <math>P[x \geq X]=P[x \geq Y], \, \forall x \in \mathbb{I}</math>.
We say two random variables <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are '''independent''' ''iff'' <math>P[y \geq Y]=P[y \geq Y | x \geq X] \land P[x \geq X]=P[x \geq X | y \geq Y] \, \forall x,y \in \mathbb{I}</math>. See {{slink|Independence (probability theory)#Two random variables}}.
==Examples== ===Uses in modeling=== The following are examples or applications of IID random variables: * A sequence of outcomes of spins of a fair or unfair [[roulette]] wheel is IID. One implication of this is that if the roulette ball lands on "red", for example, 20 times in a row, the next spin is no more or less likely to be "black" than on any other spin (see the [[Gambler's fallacy]]). * A sequence of fair or loaded dice rolls is IID * A sequence of fair or unfair coin flips is IID * In [[signal processing]] and [[image processing]] the notion of transformation to IID implies two specifications, the "ID" (ID = identically distributed) part and the "I" (I = independent) part: ** (ID) the signal level must be balanced on the time axis; ** (I) the signal spectrum must be flattened, i.e. transformed by filtering (such as [[deconvolution]]) to a [[white noise|white]] signal (one where all frequencies are equally present).
===Uses in inference=== * One of the simplest statistical tests, the [[Z-test|''z''-test]], is used to test [[null hypothesis|hypotheses]] about [[mean]]s of random variables. When using the ''z''-test, one assumes (requires) that all observations are IID in order to satisfy the conditions of the [[central limit theorem]].
==Generalizations== Many results that were first proven under the assumption that the random variables are IID have been shown to be true even under a weaker distributional assumption.
===Exchangeable random variables=== {{Main|Exchangeable random variables}} The most general notion which shares the main properties of IID variables are [[exchangeable random variables]], introduced by [[Bruno de Finetti]].{{fact|date=February 2016}} Exchangeability means that while variables may not be independent, future ones behave like past ones – formally, any value of a finite sequence is as likely as any [[permutation]] of those values – the [[joint probability distribution]] is invariant under the [[symmetric group]].
This provides a useful generalization – for example, [[sampling without replacement]] is not independent, but is exchangeable – and is widely used in [[Bayesian statistics]].
===Lévy process=== {{Main|Lévy process}} In [[stochastic calculus]], IID variables are thought of as a [[discrete time]] [[Lévy process]]: each variable gives how much one changes from one time to another. For example, a sequence of Bernoulli trials is interpreted as the [[Bernoulli process]]. One may generalize this to include continuous time Lévy processes, and many Lévy processes can be seen as limits of IID variables—for instance, the [[Wiener process]] is the limit of the Bernoulli process.
==White noise==
[[White noise]] is a simple example of IID.
==See also== * [[De Finetti's theorem]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Stochastic processes}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Independent And Identically-Distributed Random Variables}} [[Category:Independence (probability theory)]] [[Category:Statistical theory]]

revision.text:
[[Image:TamarackMiners CopperCountryMI sepia.jpg|thumb|250px|Miners pose with lunch pails in hand on a mine rock pile outside of the [[Tamarack mine|Tamarack mineshaft]].]]
Many '''[[copper]] [[Mining|mines]]''' have existed in the [[Copper Country]] of the [[United States|U.S. state]] of [[Michigan]]. These include both large-scale commercial ventures and small operations. There are hundreds of ancient mining pits in and around the Copper Country area, especially on [[Isle Royale]] (several of these were developed). Numerous small modern diggings exist around the area as well, including some around [[Fort Wilkins State Park|Fort Wilkins]] and the [[Copper Harbor Light]].
==Mines== * 543-S - near Gratiot Lake, Keweenaw County * 543-S Deposit - near Deer Lake, Keweenaw County * [[Adventure mine]] - [[Greenland, Michigan|Greenland]] * Aetna Exploration Copper mine - Keweenaw County * Aetna mine - Keweenaw County * Agate Harbor mine - Agate Harbor, Keweenaw County * Agency mine - Keweenaw County * [[Ahmeek mine]] - [[Ahmeek, Michigan|Ahmeek, Keweenaw County]] * Albion mine (originally the Manhattan Mine) - Keweenaw County * Algomah mine - Mass City, Ontonagon County * Allouez mine - Allouez, Keweenaw County * [[American Mining, Exploring, & Manufacturing Company mine]] - Isle Royale, Keweenaw County * [[Amygdaloid & Isle Royale mine|Amygdaloid and Isle Royale mine]] - Amygdaloid Island, [[Isle Royale National Park|Isle Royale]], Keweenaw County * Amygdaloid mine - Delaware, Keweenaw County * [[Arcadian mine]] - Ripley, Houghton County * Arctic mine - Victoria, Ontonagon County * Arnold mine - Copper Falls, Keweenaw County * Ashbed mine - Copper Falls, Keweenaw County * [[Atlantic Copper Mine|Atlantic Mine]] - [[Atlantic Mine, Michigan|Atlantic Mine, Houghton County]] * Atlantic Section 16 Exploration Prospect - Baltic * Baltic mine - Baltic * [[Baltic mine]] - [[South Range, Michigan|South Range, Houghton County]] * Bay State Fissure mine - Phoenix, Keweenaw County * Belt mine (originally the Piscatauqua mine) - Centennial * South Lake mine (originally the Aztec Mine) - Mass City, Ontonagon County * South Pewabic Copper Company mine * South Side mine - Houghton County * St. Clair Mine - Phoenix, Keweenaw County * St. Louis Mine Exploration - Laurium, Houghton County * Star mine - Keweenaw County * Stoutenburgh Mine - Delaware, Keweenaw County * Suffolk Exploration - Keweenaw County * Superior mine (originally the Old Superior mine) - Superior * Tamarack Junior mine - Tamarack * [[Tamarack mine]] - Tamarack * Third Island mine - Isle Royale, Keweenaw County * Toltec mine - Mass City, Ontonagon County * Tremont mine (originally the Devon mine) - Ontonagon County * Trimountain mine - Trimountain, Houghton County * Union mine (originally the Bell No. 2 mine) - Porcupine Mountains, Ontonagon County * United States Exploration Prospect - Ontonagon County * Vaughnsville Exploration Prospect - Vaughnsville, Keweenaw County * [[Victoria Mine]] (originally the Cushin mine) - [[Victoria, Michigan|Victoria, Ontonagon County]]; closed in 1921 * Vulcan Exploration Copper mine - Keweenaw County * Vulcan mine - Ontonagon County * Washington mine - Mandan, Keweenaw County * Waterbury mine - Keweenaw County * Waukulla mine - Bergland, Ontonagon County * Webster Prospect - Houghton, Houghton County * [[Wendigo mine]] - Wendigo, Isle Royale, Keweenaw County * West Caribou Island mine No. 3 - West Caribou Island, Isle Royale, Keweenaw County * West Minnesota mine - Victoria, Ontonagon County * West Vein mine - Phoenix, Keweenaw County * Wheal Kate prospect - South Range, Houghton County * [[White Pine mine]] - White Pine, Ontonagon County; the last mine to close in the Copper Country, in 1995 * Whittlesey mine - Isle Royale, Keweenaw County * Winona mine - Winona, Houghton County * Winthrop mine - Central * [[Wolverine Mine]] - Wolverine * Wyandot mine - Twin Lakes, Houghton County * Wyoming mine - Wyoming (Helltown)
== Notes == * There exist a fairly large number of unnamed mines within settlements such as Boston location, Hancock, Houghton, Hurontown, Laurium, Osceola, Oskar, Painesdale, Point Mills, Sevenmile Creek, Superior, Tamarack, Toivola, near Torch Lake, Twin Lakes, and Wolverine in Houghton County; and Copper Falls, Copper Harbor, Isle Royale, near Jacob's Creek, Mandan, Manitou Island, Ojibway, Phoenix, and Vaughsville in Keweenaw County. * Also not included on this list are the hundreds of prehistoric mining pits that exist throughout the Copper Country.
==See also== * [[Copper mining in Michigan]] * [[List of Copper Country smelters]] * [[List of Copper Country mills]] * [[Lists of copper mines in the United States]]
[[Category:Mines in Michigan|*]] [[Category:Mining-related lists|Copper Country mines]] [[Category:Michigan-related lists|Copper Country mines]]
